TRAVEL, EXPLORATION, and DISCOVERY can transform our lives. But it‚Äôs also a double-edged sword > our actions impact the destinations we visit in profound ways that many times are less than ideal. Over tourism, environmental pressure, loss of cultural identity, revenue offshoring, and strained infrastructures can all be unexpected outcomes when a destination becomes ‚Äúthe place‚Äù for the ultimate Instagram photo. These potential outcomes have destination managers constantly searching for ways to balance the economic benefits of tourism while effectively mitigating the downside risks. It‚Äôs a grand challenge. One that involves a myriad of micro-decisions that we make individually as well as our collective advocacy and support of greater, more macro-decisions made through policy, technology, education, influence, and support. The good news is that many of our industry‚Äôs best and brightest are shifting focus to developing this balance. Organizations such as Tourism Cares and The Travel Foundation, to name a few, are making outsized impacts. Many of our fastest-growing destinations, like #CostaRica, #Barbados, and #Finland, are prioritizing sustainable and meaningful travel as core KPIs. well, now on CNN. Since not many will read the whole article, here's a summary. Because, unlike life, on Camino, you've got to stick with it all the way. I don't think anyone wants to give up, because if you do, it shows you're not very resilient. And if you lack resilience, it's a problem for your professional leadership, heheh. Here's the summary: - Walking is Egalitarian: Regardless of age, gender, or economic status, the act of walking is a universal experience. Hiking the Camino revealed the remarkable capacity of the human body to cover significant distances when equipped with only the essentials. - Discovering the Essence of Spain: The Camino unveiled the rich history and diverse landscapes of Spain, from its stunning architecture to the golden fields and picturesque coastlines. It was a cultural immersion, highlighting the multifaceted beauty of this enchanting country. - Pilgrimage as a Search for Meaning: Whether driven by a spiritual quest or a desire for a more fulfilling existence, embarking on a pilgrimage is a timeless human endeavor. The Camino became a canvas for pilgrims to share their reflections on the challenges of modern life. - Embracing the Mystical: Disconnecting from daily concerns and immersing oneself in nature is a powerful practice. Slowing down, observing the surroundings, and engaging with the physical world can lead to profound emotional and spiritual experiences. - The Essence of True Travel: While modern tourism has its merits, there's a unique depth to exploring on foot. Covering distance by walking offers a genuine connection to the surroundings, encouraging spontaneous exploration and meaningful encounters. - Human Connections: Despite a world filled with skepticism, my Camino encounters affirmed the kindness of strangers. People, both locals and fellow travelers, displayed a genuine willingness to help and connect, reaffirming the enduring truth of E.M. Forster's words: "Only connect." - Self-awareness and Emotional Baggage: The journey taught me the importance of acknowledging personal limitations and the necessity of shedding both physical and emotional baggage. Self-awareness and forgiveness became the spiritual tools for a lighter, more fulfilling hike. üë£ Buen Camino #camino #resilience #connections https://lnkd.in/dcK25Npm
